refnamediv.refpurpose: Utilities to set up and manipulate vectors.

refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Utilities to set up and manipulate vectors.

refsect2.title: GimpVector2
refsect2.para: A two dimensional vector.

refsect2.title: GimpVector3
refsect2.para: A three dimensional vector.

refsect2.title: GimpVector4
refsect2.para: A four dimensional vector.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a GimpVector2 of coordinates x and y.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_set ()
refsect2.para: Sets the X and Y coordinates of vector to x and y.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_length ()
refsect2.para: Computes the length of a 2D vector.

listitem.simpara: the length of vector (a positive gdouble).

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_length_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_length() but the vector is passed by value rather than by reference.

listitem.simpara: the length of vector (a positive gdouble).

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_mul ()
refsect2.para: Multiplies each component of the vector by factor. Note that this is equivalent to multiplying the vectors length by factor.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_mul_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_mul() but the vector is passed by value rather than by reference.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_normalize ()
refsect2.para: Normalizes the vector so the length of the vector is 1.0. The nul vector will not be changed.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_normalize_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_normalize() but the vector is passed by value rather than by reference.

listitem.simpara: a GimpVector2 parallel to vector, pointing in the same direction but with a length of 1.0.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_neg ()
refsect2.para: Negates the vector (i.e. negate all its coordinates).

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_neg_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_neg() but the vector is passed by value rather than by reference.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_add ()
refsect2.para: Computes the sum of two 2D vectors. The resulting GimpVector2 is stored in result.

listitem.simpara: a pointer to the first GimpVector2.
a pointer to the second GimpVector2.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_add_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_add() but the vectors are passed by value rather than by reference.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_sub ()
refsect2.para: Computes the difference of two 2D vectors (vector1 minus vector2). The resulting GimpVector2 is stored in result.

listitem.simpara: the destination for the resulting GimpVector2.
a pointer to the first GimpVector2.
a pointer to the second GimpVector2.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_sub_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_sub() but the vectors are passed by value rather than by reference.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_inner_product ()
refsect2.para: Computes the inner (dot) product of two 2D vectors. This product is zero if and only if the two vectors are orthognal.

listitem.simpara: a pointer to the first GimpVector2.
a pointer to the second GimpVector2.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_inner_product_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_inner_product() but the vectors are passed by value rather than by reference.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_cross_product ()
refsect2.para: Compute the cross product of two vectors. The result is a GimpVector2 which is orthognal to both vector1 and vector2. If vector1 and vector2 are parallel, the result will be the nul vector.
Note that in 2D, this function is useful to test if two vectors are parallel or not, or to compute the area spawned by two vectors.

listitem.simpara: a pointer to the first GimpVector2.
a pointer to the second GimpVector2.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_cross_product_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_cross_product() but the vectors are passed by value rather than by reference.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_rotate ()
refsect2.para: Rotates the vector counterclockwise by alpha radians.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector2_rotate_val ()
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector2_rotate() but the vector is passed by value rather than by reference.

listitem.simpara: a GimpVector2 representing vector rotated by alpha radians.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector3_rotate ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gimp_vector3_rotate (GimpVector3 *vector, gdouble alpha, gdouble beta, gdouble gamma);
refsect2.para: Rotates the vector around the three axis (Z, Y, and X) by alpha, beta and gamma, respectively.

Note that the order of the rotation is very important. If you expect a vector to be rotated around X, and then around Y, you will have to call this function twice. Also, it is often wise to call this function with only one of alpha, beta and gamma non-zero.

listitem.simpara: the angle (in radian) of rotation around the Z axis.
the angle (in radian) of rotation around the Y axis.
the angle (in radian) of rotation around the X axis.

refsect2.programlisting: GimpVector3 gimp_vector3_rotate_val (GimpVector3 vector, gdouble alpha, gdouble beta, gdouble gamma);
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector3_rotate() but the vectors are passed by value rather than by reference.

listitem.simpara: the angle (in radian) of rotation around the Z axis.
the angle (in radian) of rotation around the Y axis.
the angle (in radian) of rotation around the X axis.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector_2d_to_3d ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gimp_vector_2d_to_3d (gint sx, gint sy, gint w, gint h, gint x, gint y, const GimpVector3 *vp, GimpVector3 *p);
refsect2.para: \"Compute screen (sx, sy) - (sx + w, sy + h) to 3D unit square mapping. The plane to map to is given in the z field of p. The observer is located at position vp (vp->z != 0.0).\"
In other words, this computes the projection of the point (x, y) to the plane z = p->z (parallel to XY), from the vp point of view through the screen (sx, sy)->(sx + w, sy + h)

listitem.simpara: the abscisse of the upper-left screen rectangle.
the ordinate of the upper-left screen rectangle.
the width of the screen rectangle.
the height of the screen rectangle.
the abscisse of the point in the screen rectangle to map.
the ordinate of the point in the screen rectangle to map.

refsect2.programlisting: GimpVector3 gimp_vector_2d_to_3d_val (gint sx, gint sy, gint w, gint h, gint x, gint y, GimpVector3 vp, GimpVector3 p);
refsect2.para: This function is identical to gimp_vector_2d_to_3d() but the position of the observer and the resulting point p are passed by value rather than by reference.

listitem.simpara: the abscisse of the upper-left screen rectangle.

the width of the screen rectangle.

refsect2.title: gimp_vector_3d_to_2d ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gimp_vector_3d_to_2d (gint sx, gint sy, gint w, gint h, gdouble *x, gdouble *y, const GimpVector3 *vp, const GimpVector3 *p);
refsect2.para: Convert the given 3D point to 2D (project it onto the viewing plane, (sx, sy, 0) - (sx + w, sy + h, 0). The input is assumed to be in the unit square (0, 0, z) - (1, 1, z). The viewpoint of the observer is passed in vp.
This is basically the opposite of gimp_vector_2d_to_3d().

listitem.simpara: the abscisse of the upper-left screen rectangle.
the ordinate of the upper-left screen rectangle.
the width of the screen rectangle.
the height of the screen rectangle.
the abscisse of the point in the screen rectangle to map (return value).
the ordinate of the point in the screen rectangle to map (return value).
the 3D point to project to the plane.
